user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtAssert_Message:
```c
void UtAssert_Message(uint8 MessageType, const char *File, uint32 Line, const char *Spec, ...)
{
    va_list     va;
    char        FinalMessage[256];
    const char *BaseName;
    size_t      MsgLen;

    if (File != NULL)
    {
        BaseName = strrchr(File, '/');
        if (BaseName == NULL)
        {
            BaseName = File;
        }
        else
        {
            ++BaseName;
        }
        snprintf(FinalMessage, sizeof(FinalMessage), "%s:%u:", BaseName, (unsigned int)Line);
        MsgLen = strlen(FinalMessage);
    }
    else
    {
        MsgLen = 0;
    }

    va_start(va, Spec);
    vsnprintf(&FinalMessage[MsgLen], sizeof(FinalMessage) - MsgLen, Spec, va);
    va_end(va);

    UT_BSP_DoText(MessageType, FinalMessage);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtAssert_Message:
typedef uint8_t   uint8
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
void UT_BSP_DoText(uint8 MessageType, const char *OutputMessage)
{
    char   Buffer[16];
    size_t MsgLen;
    uint32 TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL;
    uint32 MsgEnabled   = BSP_UT_Global.CurrVerbosity >> MessageType;

    if (MsgEnabled & 1)
    {
        UT_BSP_Lock();

        /* Determine if the message type warrants special treatment (color/highlight/etc). */
        switch (MessageType)
        {
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT:
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_RED;
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MIR:
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_WARN:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_RED | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_GREEN;
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TSF:
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TTF:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_RED | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_BLUE;
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_BEGIN:
                OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl("\n", 1); /* add a bit of extra whitespace between tests */
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_PASS:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_GREEN;
                break;
            default:
                break;
        }

        if (MsgEnabled <= 1)
        {
            TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL;
        }

        snprintf(Buffer, sizeof(Buffer), "[%5s]", UtAssert_GetCaseTypeAbbrev(MessageType));

        if (TermModeBits != OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL)
        {
            OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl(TermModeBits);
        }

        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(Buffer, strlen(Buffer));

        if (TermModeBits != OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL)
        {
            OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl(OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL);
        }

        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(" ", 1);
        MsgLen = strlen(OutputMessage);
        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(OutputMessage, MsgLen);
        if (MsgLen == 0 || OutputMessage[MsgLen - 1] != '\n')
        {
            OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl("\n", 1);
        }

        UT_BSP_Unlock();
    }

    /*
     * If any ABORT (major failure) message is thrown,
     * then call a BSP-provided routine to stop the test and possibly dump a core
     */
    if (MessageType == UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT)
    {
        OS_BSP_Shutdown_Impl();
    }
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No function parameter is assigned to or otherwise modified in the provided code. In UtAssert_Message the parameters are: MessageType (used but never assigned), File (examined via strrchr and not modified; a separate local pointer BaseName is assigned and incremented — this is a local variable, not the parameter), Line (used but not assigned), and Spec (used as the last named parameter for va_start and passed to vsnprintf, not modified). In UT_BSP_DoText the parameters are MessageType (used in comparisons/switch and as an argument to other functions, not assigned) and OutputMessage (read and indexed but not modified). The va_list usage does not modify any named parameter. All pointer arithmetic/assignment occurs on local pointer variables (e.g., BaseName) or on local buffers; no pointer parameter itself is changed. Therefore there are no fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in the supplied code.
